Award.AwardTitle: Modernization of the Humboldt State University Marine Laboratory Seawater System
Award.AbstractNarration:
Humboldt State University's (HSU) Marine Lab (http://www.humboldt.edu/marinelab/ ) has been awarded a grant to modernize aging components of the running seawater system which will enhance research and training activities at the lab with a reliable, high-quality system. HSU is the northernmost California State University campus and has a well-deserved reputation for high quality natural resources and science programs. The marine lab offers outstanding undergraduate and graduate instruction and excellent opportunities to carry out research projects in the lab and provides access to a wide diversity of marine and coastal habitats. The new seawater system will include two underground water tanks that provide redundancy, improve temperature regulation, are safer in an earthquake-prone region, and provide more effective utilization of the lab's limited footprint by creating space for future expansion. The new system and future expansion will significantly advance or research and training capacity in intertidal ecology, invasive species, fisheries biology, chemical, biological and geological oceanography, and climate change.

The new seawater facilities will have a positive impact on training at all levels, including K-12 classes, undergraduate and graduate fishery biology, marine biology and oceanography majors at Humboldt State University, community college faculty and students, visiting graduate students, visiting students from throughout the U.S. and the general public. Public outreach is accomplished through free public aquaria, open 6-7 days a week year-round, with guided tours, educational workshops, and high-quality displays; these facilities serve approximately 20,000-35,000 visitors/year. HSU is an Hispanic-serving institution and the only university campus along the northern California coast primarily dedicated to undergraduate education. The area is also home to a large number of Native American Tribes and Rancherias with tribal members actively collaborating in marine research and resource management projects with HSU and other institutions. The lab has a resident Marine Naturalist who leads informal marine science education efforts at the ML and other venues. In the last five years the lab has served over 5,000 K-12 students and offered 240 organized tours of the facility by multiple institutions.

Institution.Name: Humboldt State University Foundation
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: HUMBOLDT STATE UNIVERSITY SPONSORED PROGRAMS FOUNDATION

POR.DRECONTENT:
The sea water system is the core of a marine laboratory and is essential to conducting its research and training mission. With support from NSF, Humboldt State University’s (HSU) Marine Lab was awarded a grant to modernize aging components of the running seawater system to enhance research and training activities with a reliable, high-quality system. HSU is the Hispanic-serving institution and the northernmost California State University campus and has a well-deserved reputation for high quality natural resources and science programs. The marine lab offers outstanding undergraduate and graduate instruction and excellent opportunities to conduct research projects and provides access to a wide diversity of marine and coastal habitats.

The project replaced the Lab’s 50-year old above-ground aging redwood water tanks with two underground fiberglass water tanks that provide redundancy, improve temperature regulation, are safer in our earthquake-prone region, and provide more effective utilization of our limited footprint by creating space for future expansion of the lab. The intellectual merit of the new system creates significant new opportunity for future expansion which will enhance our research and training capacity in aquaculture, intertidal ecology, invasive species biology, fisheries biology, and climate change. Concurrent with the installation of the water tanks was the inclusion of a wireless instrument panel with a suite of environmental sensors in the tanks that continuously monitor water level, flow rate, temperature and conductivity with the capacity for 10 additional sensors. The data are streamed in real-time and can be accessed remotely.   

The broader impacts of the new seawater facilities will occur through training and research at multiple levels, including K-12 classes, undergraduate and graduate fishery biology, marine biology and oceanography majors at Humboldt State University, community college faculty and students, visiting graduate students and faculty, visiting scientists from throughout the U.S., and the general public. Our free public aquaria, open 6-7 days a week year-round, with guided tours, educational workshops, and high-quality displays serves 20,000-35,000 visitors/year. In the last five years we have served over 5,000 K-12 students and offered 240 organized tours of the facility for multiple institutions. Visitors to the ML are derived from almost every state in the USA and over 40 countries.

HSU is the Hispanic-serving institution and the northernmost California State University campus and has a well-deserved reputation for high quality natural resources and science programs. The marine lab offers outstanding undergraduate and graduate instruction and excellent opportunities to conduct research projects and provides access to a wide diversity of marine and coastal habitats. The intellectual merit of the new system creates significant new opportunity for future expansion which will enhance our research and training capacity in aquaculture, intertidal ecology, invasive species biology, fisheries biology, and climate change. Concurrent with the installation of the water tanks was the inclusion of a wireless instrument panel with a suite of environmental sensors in the tanks that continuously monitor water level, flow rate, temperature and conductivity with the capacity for 10 additional sensors. The data are streamed in real-time and can be accessed remotely.
